dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, I just saw a headline saying Norway is still the happiest country in the world, again. Can you believe that?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Finland? How do they even, um, measure "happy"? Sounds a bit, like, arbitrary to me.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Finland? How do they even, um, measure happy? Sounds a bit, like, arbitrary to me.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, they use six key factors. Social support, income, health, freedom, generosity, and a lack of corruption. It's all based on surveys.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, they use six key factors. Social support, income, health, freedom, generosity, and a lack of corruption. It's all based on surveys.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The World Happiness Report has been released since 2012 and evaluates six key factors to determine happiness levels in different countries: social support, income, health, freedom, generosity, and lack of corruption. These criteria are assessed based on surveys conducted among local populations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Surveys? Oh, come on. Who are they asking, and, uh, what are they really getting? Like, is Kazakhstan suddenly super happy too?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Surveys? Oh, come on. Who are they asking, and, uh, what are they really getting? Like, is Kazakhstan suddenly super happy too?

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the latest edition of the ranking, Kazakhstan secured 43rd place out of 147 countries. Compared to last year, the country jumped six positions from 49th place and outperformed all CIS countries in the "happiness index."

dialogue_turns.text: So, less happy than Kazakhstan, got it. And I bet, like, Afghanistan is still last, aren't they?

dialogue_turns.text: See, that part makes sense. But the rest of it just feels like, um, someone's just making up numbers for a, like, feel-good report.
